comment.author: 61271636@N05
comment._content: The park looks alot smaller these days.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/61271636@N05]  It is, successive realignments of York Street - now a major bus terminal, and the buiding of the city railway (1926-32) changed the character of the park. And of course the buildings that surround it now are "monsters" compared to the lovely Edwardian streetscape we see in the photograph.

The terraces in the shot are where Transport House now sits. I vaguely remember the buildings to the left, I think Selby's was in that block,  or the one next to it, along with the Sydney rep for the West Australian Newspaper, when I was despatch boy (1963!) we always said that the lift in the West Australian newspaper building was the slowest in Sydney.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
61271636@N05
comment._content: Well said John The park nowadays seems a former shadow of it's past glory, and thank you for the comparative photos pellethepoet.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/61271636@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47201412@N02] One wonders when some planning guru will suggest the whole park go only to be replaced with a bus interchange.

comment.author: 61271636@N05
comment._content: I should hope not. City Planners (gurus) need to keep their fingers to themselves and lay off destroying this Park any further.
